results.title: Can Self-Defense Laws Stand Up to a Country Awash in Guns?
results.abstract: The Kyle Rittenhouse and Ahmaud Arbery cases raise intriguing legal questions about people who take the law into their own hands and then claim self-defense when someone dies.

multimedia.caption: A detective holding the gun used by Kyle Rittenhouse last year.

results.title: ‘Alpha,’ by David Philipps: A Navy SEAL’s Behavior Worried Teammates and Changed How They Fought
results.abstract: In a new book, a Times reporter details the SEALs culture that fostered Eddie Gallagher’s rise and sheds new light on the events that led to his trial (and acquittal) in a polarizing war crimes case.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: Navy Special Operations Chief Edward Gallagher arriving at military court at Naval Base San Diego in June 2019. Chief Gallagher, who was on trial for war crimes, was acquitted on the most serious charges.

results.title: Jury Must Weigh Complex Legal Questions Before Kyle Rittenhouse Verdict
results.abstract: Jury deliberations, expected to start next week, will include consideration of six separate criminal counts. The jurors may be instructed to consider lesser charges as well.

multimedia.caption: Kyle Rittenhouse, center, watching an evidence video on Friday with his lawyer Mark Richards, right, and Judge Bruce Schroeder.

results.title: Lawyer for Man Accused of Killing Ahmaud Arbery Draws Scrutiny
results.abstract: Kevin Gough argued that the Rev. Al Sharpton’s presence in court was intimidating to the jury. “We don’t want any more Black pastors coming in here,” he said.

multimedia.caption: Kevin Gough is a lawyer for William Bryan, one of the three men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia last year.

results.title: Flooding and Nuclear Waste Eat Away at a Tribe’s Ancestral Home
results.abstract: The federal government allowed a stockpile of spent fuel on a Minnesota reservation to balloon even as a dam project whittled down the amount of livable land.

multimedia.caption: The state of Minnesota and the federal government ignored warnings about potential issues from flooding and nuclear waste posed to put the Prairie Island Indian Community in danger.
multimedia.copyright: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times

results.title: How the U.S. Hid an Airstrike That Killed Dozens of Civilians in Syria
results.abstract: The military never conducted an independent investigation into a 2019 bombing on the last bastion of the Islamic State, despite concerns about a secretive commando force.
results.byline: By Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: Fleeing heavy bombardment in Baghuz, Syria — the Islamic State’s last holdout — on March 18, 2019.

results.title: What’s in Chris Christie’s New Book?
results.abstract: I recently interviewed Chris Christie, who has a book coming out. Here are the most interesting parts.

results.title: Chris Christie Wants the Post-Trump G.O.P. to Move Past 2020
results.abstract: In a new book and in an interview, Mr. Christie says that if the former president wants to be a positive force, “he’s got to let this other stuff go.”
des_facet: Republican Rescue: Saving the Party From Truth Deniers, Conspiracy Theorists, and the Dangerous Policies of Joe Biden (Book)

multimedia.caption: Chris Christie says his new book is not about Donald J. Trump, but “about where we go from here and why it is important for us to let go of the past.”
multimedia.copyright: Al Drago for The New York Times

results.title: Doctor Charged With False Report to Summon Helicopter on Denali
results.abstract: Federal prosecutors said the climber called rescuers to say that two other people on the mountain, the tallest in North America, were having a medical emergency. But it was a ruse.

multimedia.caption: Denali park rangers warned they had seen “a disturbing amount of overconfidence paired with inexperience” in the first month of the mountain’s 2021 climbing season.

results.title: Man Pardoned After Spending 24 Years in Prison for Murder
results.abstract: The pardon came after a North Carolina judge vacated the conviction of Montoyae Dontae Sharpe in 2019, ruling that a key witness had “entirely made up” her testimony.

multimedia.caption: Montoyae Dontae Sharpe in 2019 after a judge ruled he could be set free. The North Carolina governor on Friday granted Mr. Sharpe a pardon.
multimedia.copyright: Deborah Griffin/The Daily Reflector, via Associated Press

results.title: Appeals Court Extends Block on Biden’s Vaccine Mandate for Employers
results.abstract: A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit held that challengers were likely to succeed in their claim that the mandate was an unlawful overreach.

multimedia.caption: A protest against vaccine mandates this week in San Francisco.

results.title: Project Veritas Tells Judge It Was Assured Biden Diary Was Legally Obtained
results.abstract: But a search warrant in the case suggests the Justice Department believes the diary kept by the president’s daughter Ashley Biden was stolen.
results.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Goldman

multimedia.caption: Federal authorities searched the home of the Project Veritas founder, James O’Keefe, last week.
multimedia.copyright: Jae S. Lee/The Dallas Morning News, via Associated Press

results.title: Homer Plessy’s Arrest in 1892 Led to a Landmark Ruling. Now He May Get Justice.
results.abstract: His legacy is tied to a Supreme Court decision that upheld the “separate but equal” doctrine, underpinning laws that segregated and disenfranchised African Americans for decades.

multimedia.caption: A mural outside of Homer Plessy Community School in New Orleans. The Louisiana Board of Pardons voted on Friday to clear his record, nearly 130 years after he was arrested for sitting in a whites-only car on a train in Louisiana.

results.title: 2 Ivory Smugglers Captured in International Operation, U.S. Says
results.abstract: The men were captured by relying on DNA sampling from a previously seized ivory haul, which helped experts pinpoint the location of poached elephants.

multimedia.caption: Some of the $3.5 million worth of ivory and rhino horn seized in the operation.

results.title: In France, Kamala Harris Searches for Role on Global Stage
results.abstract: The vice president met with President Emmanuel Macron of France, skirting recent U.S.-French tensions, and immersed herself in issues like Libya and cybersecurity.
results.byline: By Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

multimedia.caption: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Vice President Kamala Harris in Paris on Friday.

results.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
results.abstract: The future of work

multimedia.caption: Daily reported coronavirus cases in the United States, seven-day average.

results.title: Read the Indictment
results.abstract: A grand jury indicted Stephen K. Bannon, a former Trump aide, on two counts of contempt of Congress after he refused to comply with subpoenas in a House committee’s investigation of the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

results.title: Bannon Indicted on Contempt Charges Over House’s Capitol Riot Inquiry
results.abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, a former top aide to Donald Trump, had refused to comply with subpoenas from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on Congress.
results.byline: By Katie Benner and Luke Broadwater

multimedia.caption: Stephen K. Bannon had refused last month to comply with subpoenas for information issued by the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
multimedia.copyright: Carlos Bernate for The New York Times

results.title: Democrats’ Bill Would Deny For-Profit College Students Extra Aid
results.abstract: Critics say a little-noticed provision would hurt the very constituencies — people of color, the working class, low-income Americans — that the party typically champions.

multimedia.caption: The ITT Technical Institute was one of the country’s largest for-profit schools before it went under in 2016.
multimedia.copyright: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times

results.title: 20 People Rescued From Flooded R.V. Park in Oregon
results.abstract: Some campers were airlifted from a recreational vehicle park after floodwaters covered the only bridge in and out of the area.

multimedia.caption: Flooding in Otis, Ore., swamped a fire truck and prompted the evacuation of a recreational vehicle park near the coast.

results.title: Qatar to Represent U.S. Interests in Afghanistan, Blinken Says
results.abstract: The Gulf nation will also help process visas for thousands of people trying to flee the Taliban.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani of Qatar and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the State Department in Washington on Friday.

results.title: Menace Enters the Republican Mainstream
results.abstract: Threats of violence have become commonplace among a significant part of the party, as historians and those who study democracy warn of a dark shift in American politics.
results.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Astead W. Herndon

multimedia.caption: Rioters at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Polling suggests that 30 percent of Republicans believe that “true patriots” may have to resort to violence to “save” the country.
multimedia.copyright: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

results.title: Biden and China’s Xi Will Hold Virtual Summit on Monday
results.abstract: The leaders of the world’s two largest economies confront tensions over trade, cyberthreats, the climate, Taiwan and human rights.

multimedia.caption: A virtual summit between President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China has been in the works since early October.

results.title: Murkowski Announces Re-election Bid, Setting Up Clash With Trump
results.abstract: Of the seven Republicans who found former President Donald J. Trump guilty in his second impeachment trial, the Alaska senator is the only one facing re-election this year.

multimedia.caption: Senator Lisa Murkowski, first appointed to the Senate in 2002 by her father after he became governor and resigned from the seat, is the second-most-senior Republican woman.
multimedia.copyright: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

results.title: Husband of ‘Sweetheart Swindler’ Sentenced to 85 Years for Bilking Older People
results.abstract: Prosecutors said that Desiree Boltos and her husband, Paul Hill, stole more than $3 million from seniors who believed they were in romantic relationships with her.

multimedia.caption: Desiree Boltos and Paul Hill

results.title: Biden Chooses Robert Califf to Lead F.D.A., Despite Drug Industry Ties
results.abstract: Dr. Robert M. Califf, an academic and clinical trial researcher who ran the agency in 2016, has also consulted for pharmaceutical companies.
results.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Sheila Kaplan

multimedia.caption: If Dr. Robert M. Califf, center, is confirmed by the Senate, he will again take the reins of an agency that is responsible for more than $2.8 trillion worth of food, medical products and tobacco.

results.title: See’s Turns 100. Plus Other Quintessentially California Foods.
results.abstract: Avocados, In-N-Out Burger, sourdough bread and more.

results.title: Black Farmworkers Say They Lost Jobs to Foreigners Who Were Paid More
results.abstract: Longtime field laborers in the Mississippi Delta said in a lawsuit that they were asked to train white guest workers from South Africa before losing their jobs to them.
results.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Sarahbeth Maney

multimedia.caption: Richard Strong in a cotton field near Highway 82 in Indianaola, Miss. Mr. Strong is a plaintiff in a case suing Southern farm owners for illegally using the H-2A visa program to deny Americans work.
